skills.name: Compare the gradient of two linear functions where one is given algebraically and one is given as a graph.
Compare the gradient of two linear functions where one is given algebraically and one is given as a table of values.
Compare the gradient of two linear functions where one is given as a table of values and one is given as a graph.
Compare the y-intercept of two linear functions where one is given algebraically and one is given as a table of values
Compare the y-intercept of two linear functions where one is given algebraically and one is given as a graph

explanations.A: Tom's function has a rate of change of 3. Katie's function has a rate of change of 1/2 as ğ‘¦ increases by 5 for every 10 of ğ‘¥. Therefore, Tom's function has a higher rate of change.
explanations.B: Not quite - a rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. Try comparing two columns in Katie's table to see what the rate of change is.
explanations.C: They can't both be true, as it's not possible for both rates to be greater than each other at the same time. In a function, the rate of change is given by the slope. In a table, the rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. Which one would give us a greater rate?
explanations.D: Unless the representations both have exactly the same rate of change, one must be greater than the other. In a function, the rate of change is given by the slope. In a table, the rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. Which one would give us a greater rate?

explanations.A: Not quite - a rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. Try comparing two columns in Katie's table to see what the rate of change is.
explanations.B: Rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. When Katie's table increases ğ‘¥ by 5, ğ‘¦ increases by 25, meaning the rate of change is 25/5 = 5. This is higher than the rate of change of 2 in Tom's function.
explanations.C: They can't both be true, as it's not possible for both rates to be greater than each other at the same time. In a function, the rate of change is given by the slope. In a table, the rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. Which one would give us a greater rate?
explanations.D: Unless the representations both have exactly the same rate of change, one must be greater than the other. In a function, the rate of change is given by the slope. In a table, the rate of change can be calculated by difference in ğ‘¦ Ã· difference in ğ‘¥. Which one would give us a greater rate?

explanations.A: I think you may have mixed up the ğ‘¦-intercept and the rate of change. Rate of change from a graph is given by the slope.
explanations.B: Tom's graph has a slope of -4, meaning the rate of change is 4. This is less than Katie's function which has a slope of 6.
explanations.C: Not quite - the rate of change given from a function is always the number that is attached to 'ğ‘¥'. See if you can compare Katie's function with the slope of Tom's graph.
explanations.D: Unless the representations both have exactly the same rate of change, one must be greater than the other. Try calculating the slope of Tom's graph and comparing it to the slope of Katie's function.

explanations.A: I think you may have mixed up the ğ‘¦-intercept and the rate of change. Rate of change from a graph is given by the slope.
explanations.B: Tom's graph has a slope of -4, meaning the rate of change is 4. This is less than Katie's function which has a rate of change of 10.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you've compared the rate of change from the graph with the ğ‘¦-intercept in Katie's function - the rate of change given from a function is always the number that is attached to 'ğ‘¥'.
explanations.D: Unless the representations both have exactly the same rate of change, one must be greater than the other. Try calculating the rate of change of Tom's graph and comparing it to the slope of Katie's function.

explanations.A: Not quite! The rate of change from a table and a graph can be calculated by difference in y Ã· difference in x. See if you can work it out for both Tom and Katie!
explanations.B: Not quite! The rate of change from a table and a graph can be calculated by difference in y Ã· difference in x. See if you can work it out for both Tom and Katie!
explanations.C: Can both be correct if they're both saying theirs is greater? Two numbers cannot be greater than each other at the same time!
explanations.D: Both Tom and Katie's representations have a rate of change of 5/3. This means that neither of them are right because they're exactly the same!

explanations.A: Not quite! The rate of change from a table and a graph can be calculated by difference in y Ã· difference in x. See if you can work it out for both Tom and Katie!
explanations.B: Not quite! The rate of change from a table and a graph can be calculated by difference in y Ã· difference in x. See if you can work it out for both Tom and Katie!
explanations.C: Can both be correct if they're both saying theirs is greater? Two numbers cannot be greater than each other at the same time!
explanations.D: Both Tom and Katie's representations have a rate of change of 4. This means that neither of them are right because they're exactly the same!

explanations.A: The ğ‘¦-intercept from a table can be found when ğ‘¥ = 0. In Tom's function, the ğ‘¦-intercept is 10, and in Katie's table, the ğ‘¦-intercept is 0. This means Tom's function has a greater ğ‘¦-intercept.
explanations.B: Not quite - the ğ‘¦-intercept from a table can be found by looking for when ğ‘¥ = 0. What would that make Katie's ğ‘¦-intercept?
explanations.C: Not quite - the ğ‘¦-intercept from a table can be found by looking for when ğ‘¥ = 0. What would that make Katie's ğ‘¦-intercept?
explanations.D: This would be the case if they both had the same ğ‘¦-intercept, but they don't! In a function, the ğ‘¦-intercept is the number that is by itself, not attached to ğ‘¥. In a table, the ğ‘¦-intercept is the ğ‘¦-value when ğ‘¥ = 0.

explanations.A: Not quite - the ğ‘¦-intercept from a table can be found by looking for when ğ‘¥ = 0. What would that make Katie's ğ‘¦-intercept?

explanations.C: Not quite - the ğ‘¦-intercept from a table can be found by looking for when ğ‘¥ = 0. What would that make Katie's ğ‘¦-intercept?
explanations.D: This would be the case if they both had the same ğ‘¦-intercept, but they don't! In a function, the ğ‘¦-intercept is the number that is by itself, not attached to ğ‘¥. In a table, the ğ‘¦-intercept is the ğ‘¦-value when ğ‘¥ = 0.

explanations.A: The ğ‘¦-intercept of a graph is where the line passes through the vertical ğ‘¦-axis. This graph passes through at 6, so it has a higher ğ‘¦-intercept than Katie's function which is -5.
explanations.B: I think you might have compared the rates of change here rather than the ğ‘¦-intercept!
explanations.C: Not quite - the ğ‘¦-intercept from a function is the number on it's own. I think you might have compared the rate of change of the function with the ğ‘¦-intercept of the graph.
explanations.D: Unless the representations both have exactly the same ğ‘¦-intercept, one must be greater than the other. See if you can spot which one is bigger!

explanations.A: The ğ‘¦-intercept of a graph is where the line passes through the vertical ğ‘¦-axis. This graph passes through at 10, so it has a higher ğ‘¦-intercept than Katie's function which is -4.
explanations.B: I think you might have compared the rates of change with the ğ‘¦-intercept here! The ğ‘¦-intercept of a function is always the number by itself, never the number attached to ğ‘¥.
